<t> The User Interface Designer and the Industrial Designer presented their prototypes to the group. </t>  <t> Two prototypes featured different fruit shapes, with one including speech recognition instead of a large number of buttons. </t>  <t> It also featured scroll wheels for channel control. </t>  <t> The other prototype was designed like a banana with children users in mind. </t>  <t> The Project Manager announced to the group that with all of their desired features, the project would go over the alotted budget; after a reanalysis of the features of the prototype, the project came in under the budget instead. </t>  <t> It was decided that another feature could possibly be added. </t>  <t> The group evaluated their effectiveness as a team and felt that all members worked well together and could be creative, and that the project had very good leadership. </t>  <t> The Marketing Expert led an evaluation of the prototype according to the initial project goals; the evaluation showed that most of the goals had been sufficiently satisfied in order to launch the product. </t>  <t> The remote will come in several designs: two will have different fruit or vegetable shapes, one of which will feature speech recognition in lieu of a large number of buttons. </t>  <t> There will also be a child-friendly banana-shaped remote. </t>  <t> Both the company name and slogan will appear on the remote. </t>  <t> The remotes will be bundled with a yellow charging stand. </t>  <t> The devices were made with a latex product with a rubbery texture. </t>  <t> It was decided that the product had met enough of the initial project goals to be launched on the market. </t>  <t> The Project Manager felt that the group had been too constrained by the budget. </t>  <t> Some felt that the banana shape would not appeal to enough of the market and that there was not enough variety in shape in the remotes to make up for this problem. </t>

<t> The Industrial Designer presented an analysis of cost and the manufacturing options that were available to the group. </t>  <t> The Marketing Expert presented market trends and the organic trend that this project would adopt. </t>  <t> She discussed materials that could be used to follow this trend. </t>  <t> The User Interface Designer presented several interface concepts including voice recognition, a spinning wheel design, and a touch screen interface. </t>  <t> The group then discussed the features of the device. </t>  <t> They discussed the costs and benefits of using either voice recognition or the touch screen interface, and decided on voice recognition based on their marketing data that favored it. </t>  <t> They decided to use solar power to power the device. </t>  <t> The group discussed the non-traditional look the device could have since the voice recognition would allow it to be stationary. </t>  <t> They discussed using rubber for the case. </t>  <t> The group talked about hiding the complicated functions from the main interface, using rubber for the buttons, and having different cases to suit different tastes. </t>  <t> The Project Manager reiterated that the product was being marketed towards the youth market, and then gave out assignments and instructed the group to work together to build the prototype. </t>  <t> The Industrial Designer, the User Interface Designer, and the Marketing Expert were instructed to work together on making the prototype of the remote control. </t>  <t> The Industrial Designer will build the look of the device using the new manufacturing constraints that were presented. </t>  <t> The User Interface Designer was assigned the task of making the design layout of the device. </t>  <t> The Marketing Expert was instructed to check the evaluations of the prototype. </t>  <t> The group realized that it would be too costly to add both a voice recognition component and a touch screen, so they decided between the two and will now only add the voice recognition component. </t>  <t> The group decided to have optional alternative cases for the device to suit different consumer tastes. </t>  <t> It was also decided that the remote will not have the traditional look of a hand-held remote since it can be stationary with voice recognition software. </t>  <t> The remote control will be made of a soft rubber material. </t>  <t> The device will be powered by solar power, with a small backup battery. </t>  <t> There were difficulties deciding between adding extra features and staying within the project budget. </t>  <t> The participants had problems projecting how much each added feature would drive up the price point of the device because there was a lack of data on manufacturing cost. </t>

<t> The project manager opens the meeting by going through notes from the last meeting, recapping the topics covered. </t>  <t> He tells them some new project requirements given by management. </t>  <t> The marketing expert presents, talking about user functionality requirements taken from research of 100 people. </t>  <t> They discuss the possibility of making a remote that hides less frequently used buttons, one that uses voices recognition to eliminate buttons altogether, or one that combines the two functions. </t>  <t> The interface specialist presents, showing examples of two different products- one that is user-centered and another that is engineering-centered and giving personal preference to the simpler one because it is easier to use and has fewer buttons. </t>  <t> Next the industrial designer presents, explaining how a remote control works and giving personal preference to a remote which has a large energy source such as a rechargable battery or battery dock. </t>  <t> The group discusses using a battery that will last 5-10 years or a solar combined with a battery. </t>  <t> They briefly review their discussions and close the meeting. </t>  <t> Teletext no longer important given rise of internet and thus will not be used. </t>  <t> The remote will be for television only. </t>  <t> Device will incorporate company logo and colors. </t>  <t> The remote will be extremely simple. </t>  <t> The remote will be a radiaclly different shape. </t>  <t> The remote will have few buttons, but the main ones such as channel, volume, on/off. </t>  <t> Whether to use voice recognition. </t>  <t> What type of battery to use - long-lasting ordinary battery or solar + regular battery. </t>  <t> Whether to use changable covers. </t>

<t> The User Interface Designer presented the major components of the interface design, dividing the interface into two parts: voice commands and buttons. </t>  <t> The Marketing Expert went over users' requirements as seen in a company study and showed that the major complaint was that remotes were too difficult to use. </t>  <t> She also showed that users want fancier and more ergonomic designs, shock protection, voice recognition, and LCD screens. </t>  <t> The Project Manager announced a new requirement to the group, that the remote is only to control televisions. </t>  <t> The Industrial Designer gave a layout of the internal functions of the device and showed that a standard chip, instead of a larger one that would accomodate voice recognition, would be the most feasible. </t>  <t> The Project Manager announced also that the group was not to include a teletext function and that they should integrate the company logo into the external design. </t>  <t> The group decided on what button functions should be included and decided to eliminate the LCD screen and voice recognition from the design due to time and cost restraints. </t>  <t> The group decided to include a previous channel change button to the standard remote buttons, and to have a wheel for changing channels in increments, with a smaller number pad below it. </t>  <t> The remote will not have an LCD screen. </t>  <t> The remote will not include speech recognition. </t>  <t> The group experienced many technical difficulties with their presentations; all participants encountered problems when opening their presentations. </t>

design. </t>  <t> A fruit and vegetable theme and spongy materials are popular trends that will be used in the design. </t>  <t> The group finalized which features they wanted to integrate into the design. </t>  <t> They decided to make the remote shaped like a banana and spongy, to have the buttons lighted, to have a wheel sensor at the top of the device, and to use only a standard chip and battery that would not accomodate speech recognition. </t>  <t> The Project Manager instructed the User Interface Designer and the Industrial Designer to construct the prototype, and announced that remote will be shaped and colored like a banana, and be covered in a spongy material. </t>  <t> The buttons will be lighted. </t>  <t> The group decided to keep the wheel sensor despite the added cost. </t>  <t> It will be placed at the top of the banana shape. </t>  <t> The group decided to simply use a standard chip that will not accomodate speech recognition, as this feature will be <t> The project manager opens the meeting, stating that it is about conceptual design. </t>  <t> He restates the last meeting's descision that they will not do speech recognition technology but says they still have to decide whether to use an LCD screen. </t>  <t> Then they move on to the three presentations. </t>  <t> The marketing expert is first to present, and he talks about making a pleasant-looking device, particularly one that favors current trends. </t>  <t> They then begin talking about using a fruit, vegetable, or natural object as the shape of the remote, the logo, or for the buttons. </t>  <t> Eventually they decide to make the device the shape of a banana. </t>  <t> Next, the user interface specialist presents. </t>  <t> He annouces that the technology division of their company has developed an integrated programmeable sample speaker unit, which would allow a person to have a conversation with the remote control. </t>  <t> They have the option of using that technology. </t>  <t> He shows them his plan what the remote control could look like and the features it might have. </t>  <t> He suggests putting two scroll wheels- one for changing the channel and another for the volume. </t>  <t> He also included a turbo button for speed, which he thinks every design should have. </t>  <t> Since they can only charge twenty-five euro they decide to eliminate the LCD screen idea. </t>  <t> After that the interface specialist talks about having a base station for the purpose of finding the remote control when lost. </t>  <t> The user could simply press a button on the base station and the remote control would start beeping. </t>  <t> Lastly, the industrial designer presents, discussing the power source of the remote control. </t>  <t> He suggests that they could have one of two kinds of power supplies- the usual batteries or rechargable ones if there is to be a base station and they could place solar cells on top for times when the lighting is good. </t>  <t> He talks about using plastic with elasticity so that the remote would not break into pieces if it fell, which relates to their earlier discussion about giving it a spongy design. </t>  <t> Plastic is also less costly than other options of wood or titanum. </t>  <t> In addition, he talks about giving the control a double curve, curves on both the sides so that it is easy to hold and handle. </t>  <t> They do not yet seem set about the idea of making it a banana shape, and one group member feels that the shape is not handy. </t>  <t> The industrial desiger tells them they will use a regular chip rather than the advanced one since pricing is a factor. </t>  <t> They agree on having base station with the remote. </t>  <t> They go on to have discussion, with one member suggesting that they make the banana more stylized so that it looks less like a banana- for example, it could be silver. </t>  <t> After that the project manager has them discuss/reiterate the decisions made during the meeting:  no LCD screen, the remote will have a base station, a RF for beeping, a button on the base station to press, possibly a stylish banana-shape for the control, 2 scroll wheels to control the volume and channels at the thumb level, a turbo button perhaps underneath the device, on/off button for the TV. </t>  <t> Before the next meeting, the interface specialist and industrial designer have to work together on the user interface and the look/feel design. </t>  <t> The marketing expert has to look up product evaluation. </t>  <t> Thus far, LCD and ASR have been ruled out. </t>  <t> The remote will have a base station, a button on the base station to press, 2 scroll wheels for the channels and volume, a turbo button (possibly underneath the device), and an on/off button for the TV. </t>  <t> The group has not yet agreed on whether the remote should be banana-shaped. </t>  <t> There is concern that the shape is not handy and might make the product less marketable- that would be a problem since they have to meet the fifty million euros profit goal. </t>

<t> This last meeting started with the presentation of a remote control prototype. </t>  <t> It has on-off and volume buttons, an LCD screen (it can be active or switched off) in various colours, which largely replaces the use of push buttons, and a jog-wheel for navigation and option selection in the menus presented on the LCD. </t>  <t> It also includes speech recognition as an alternative interface, which also serves as mechanism for locating the device. </t>  <t> It was designed to be powered by a single battery. </t>  <t> The casing will be made of titanium with rubber strawberries following the fruit and veg fashion. </t>  <t> The prototype was evaluated on a scale of 1(excellent)-7(very bad) in terms of fancifulness, technology, robustness, usefulness, size, colour and shape and customizability: the average mark was 2.17; the team were satisfied with their prototype, although after costs were calculated it proved very expensive. </t>  <t> Finally, the team evaluated the whole process: they deemed themselves a good team, they found there was plenty of room for creativity and they liked the project manager's leadership. </t>  <t> *NA* </t>  <t> After the team realised the prototype was over budget, they replaced the battery with a hand dynamo. </t>  <t> When it became evident from the costs of components and materials that they would have to do without either the LCD or the speech recognition, they decided to change the given prices in order to accommodate them to their design and budget. </t>  <t> The gratuitous presence of decorative rubber strawberries on a titanium case (even if they cover sensors) did not meet everyone's approval. </t>  <t> Although, the attempt was towards keeping with the current fashion trends, the result did not satisfy the program manager. </t>  <t> The prototype was more than 40% over budget. </t>  <t> The team realised that their budget did not allow for all the specifications of their prototype. </t>

<t> The Project Manager presented the goals of the meeting and new product requirements. </t>  <t> The Industrial Designer presented the internal components of a remote control and showed a diagram of how they operate together. </t>  <t> He suggested that field programmable gateway arrays be used for the chip controlling software functionalities, and it was suggested that the remote be used with a recharging stand. </t>  <t> The User Interface Designer gave a presentation on the technical functions of the remote, and displayed the interfaces of two existing products for comparison. </t>  <t> He showed that the competitors' remotes were too complicated. </t>  <t> He suggested that the televisions that the remotes are used with connect to the internet to access downloadable programs. </t>  <t> He suggested a simple design with few buttons, small size, and a locator function. </t>  <t> The Marketing Expert presented several characteristics important to users. </t>  <t> He discussed using speech recognition and ways to make it feasible for the project, small size, low price point, and incorporating teletext in different languages. </t>  <t> The group discussed the new requirement that required them to omit teletext from their design, and discussed the possibility of using the remote to access the internet through the television. </t>  <t> The remote will be used with a recharging stand. </t>  <t> The group decided not to include a lighting adaptation system. </t>  <t> The participants disagreed on how to easily move through channels using the design of the User Interface Designer, which included very few buttons. </t>  <t> There was no resolution on whether or not to allow users to use the remote to access the internet through their television, as opposed to including teletext capabilities. </t>

voice recognition; either push, scroll, or spinning buttons; and incorporating some customizable components. </t>  <t> The group discussed including a help button; it was decided that it would make the device seem more complicated. </t>  <t> The Marketing Expert presented that users found remotes too easily lost, complicated, and ugly. </t>  <t> He showed that users were willing to pay more for a fancy remote. </t>  <t> He suggested the LCD screen; the group felt that it was better to utilize the user's television as a display screen, but that they would inquire about cost before deciding. </t>  <t> The group will inquire about the cost of voice recognition and scroll buttons. </t>  <t> The group discussed incorporating a locator function and customization for children. </t>  <t> They discussed the sensitivity of the voice recognizer to other noises; the group will ask about the capability of the recognizer. </t>  <t> The group will find out if the kinetic energy component can provide enough energy. </t>  <t> The group will inquire about the cost of voice recognition and the scroll button. </t>  <t> The group will ask about the capability of the voice recognition component. </t>  <t> The group decided not to include a help button on the device because it would make the remote seem more complicated. </t>  <t> There was not enough information about the capabilities of the voice recognizer or the kinetic energy source. </t>  <t> There was not enough information on the cost of several components. </t>  <t> No decision was made about whether or not the LCD screen should be included. </t>  <t> No decision was made about including a locator function, or what form it should take. </t>  <t> No decision was made about making the remote programmable for children. </t>

<t> The User Interface Designer and the Industrial Designer presented two prototypes, one with an LCD screen and one without. </t>  <t> They demonstrated how to navigate through the menus and presented the voice recognition and energy source components and the charging stand. </t>  <t> They discussed their modular design. </t>  <t> They discussed the parental control module and the titanium casing. </t>  <t> The production costs were below budget for the basic models. </t>  <t> The Marketing Expert presented three important user requirements, and also the fruit and vegetable and spongy material trends in fashion. </t>  <t> He then led an evaluation of the prototypes according to these requirements. </t>  <t> The group did not feel that the remotes sufficiently met the criteria. </t>  <t> They decided to continue working on the design and to take out the LCD screen and voice recognition. </t>  <t> They discussed the modular design and its advantages in attracting customers. </t>  <t> The group discussed how to incorporate the fashion trends; it was suggested that one shape was used, which could be customized with skins. </t>  <t> The Project Manager led an evaluation of the group's experience on the project. </t>  <t> The group was pleased with the teamwork and leadership, but one participant complained that not enough information was given about each meeting's agenda. </t>  <t> The User Interface Designer and the Industrial Designer will look into options for spongy skin materials. </t>  <t> The remote will feature rechargeable double-A batteries and a charging stand. </t>  <t> The remote can be customized for adults, children, or the elderly. </t>  <t> The remote has a misplacement reminder that sends a message to the television screen to remind users to put the remote back in the charger when not in use. </t>  <t> The remote features a modular design that allows users to add as many or as few components as they wish to the basic model. </t>  <t> The group was unsatisfied with the design and decided to continue working on it, focusing on a fancier design. </t>  <t> The remote will not feature an LCD screen or voice recognition. </t>  <t> The group decided that the teamwork and leadership of the project were good, but that not enough information was given about each meeting's agenda. </t>  <t> The group had difficulty deciding what would be displayed on the LCD screen. </t>  <t> The group felt that too much focus was placed on the functionality of the remote such that they could not achieve a fancy look. </t>  <t> The group did not feel that the prototype met the user requirements presented by the Marketing Expert. </t>  <t> The group could not decide how to incorporate the fashion trends into the design. </t>  <t> Not enough information was given about the agenda of each meeting. </t>

interface designer talked about what functions should be included. </t>  <t> He suggested they should focus on either expert or novice users. </t>  <t> The basic functions should include an on/off switch, buttons for channels one to nine, volume, mute and buttons for next and previous channel. </t>  <t> He suggested that a trendy design should not have many buttons. </t>  <t> The marketing expert reported on user requirements, including how users rated the importance of different features. </t>  <t> He stressed that a trendy design is important, that users zap a lot, and that remotes often get lost. </t>  <t> The project manager informed the group of new requirements. </t>  <t> The remote is only for TV, should not include a teletext feature, and should feature the company colour and slogan. </t>  <t> The group discussed what functions and features the remote should have, and whether to include DVD/VCR controls, a teletext button, stop button, changeable covers, and a base/recharger with locator function. </t>  <t> The group also discussed making the remote a rounded, ergonomic shape, and using flashing lights to help locate it when lost. </t>  <t> The project than wood or titanium. </t>  <t> He also recommended using basic batteries rather than solar or kinetic power. </t>  <t> He also mentioned the possibility of using an LCD screen to add something special. </t>  <t> The user interface designer went over the functions to be included in the remote. </t>  <t> The group discussed using large buttons for the most frequently used functions. </t>  <t> market also likes the theme of fruit and vegetables and spongy material, which could be implemented through fruity colours and using a spongy material for the base. </t>  <t> The group discussed how to incorporate a fruit and vegetable theme, as well as the company colours and logo. </t>  <t> The group discussed whether to include an LCD screen, and eventually decided against it. </t>  <t> The project manager closed the meeting and told the group they would receive emails about their tasks for the next meeting. </t>  <t> The project manager will write up the minutes and put them in the shared folder, using a keyboard instead of the digital pen. </t>  <t> The rest of the group will receive instructions via email. </t>  <t> The remote will not feature an LCD screen. </t>  <t> The remote will be available in different colour schemes, but not with changeable fronts. </t>  <t> The case will be made of plastic and rubber. </t>  <t> The remote will feature power, skip, volume, mute, teletext and menu buttons. </t>  <t> The project manager had problems using the digital pen to write the minutes. </t>  <t> The group were not sure to what extent the remote should incorporate the fruit and vegetable theme. </t>  <t> The industrial designer was keen to incorporate an LCD screen, but the others were not so sure. </t>  <t> The group were not sure whether to use plastic and rubber or titanium for the case. </t>  <t> They were not sure how to use fruity colours without being too flashy. </t>

<t> The project manager opened the meeting. </t>  <t> The user interface designer and industrial designer presented the prototype design. </t>  <t> The remote has buttons for power, mute, teletext, volume and channel up/down, and nine numbered channel buttons. </t>  <t> The group discussed what buttons would be needed to enter channels 10 and above. </t>  <t> They discussed adapting the docking station so it could be used with other products but did not make a decision. </t>  <t> The remote is plastic with different coloured rubber strips on the sides and rubber buttons. </t>  <t> The marketing expert led the product evaluation. </t>  <t> The group were generally satisfied with the design but did not think the remote was technologically innovative. </t>  <t> The overall score was 2.6. </t>  <t> The group worked out the manufacturing costs. </t>  <t> The group had problems figuring out the cost of the docking station and buttons, and did not know which kind of chip to use. </t>  <t> They discussed using kinetic energy to make the remote more technologically innovative but decided against it. </t>  <t> They eventually decided that they could not afford a docking station. </t>  <t> They did not have time to evaluate the project process before the end of the meeting. </t>  <t> The group will fill out a final questionnaire. </t>  <t> The remote will use a simple chip. </t>  <t> The remote will use a standard battery and not kinetic energy. </t>  <t> The remote will not come with a docking station. </t>  <t> The group could not agree what buttons would be needed to enter channels 10 and above. </t>  <t> The could not decide whether the docking station should be adapted for use with other products. </t>  <t> The group did not know how much the docking station would cost. </t>  <t> They were not sure what kind of chip they would need or where to find this information. </t>  <t> They were not sure how much the buttons would cost because they seemed too expensive. <t> There are some new requirements for the project: the device will have to be for TV only, they should ignore the teletext function, as it is dated, and, also, the remote should be recognisable as a Real Reaction product. </t>  <t> The target group will be people below 30. </t>  <t> It transpires that customers are willing to pay more for fancier looking remotes, especially if they include LCD screens and speech recognition. </t>  <t> Functions like zapping are very prevalent, as well as complaints about remotes being difficult to learn and easy to lose. </t>  <t> The function of the remote is relatively simple: by pressing a button a current is passed to the chip, and defines what signal is to be sent to the receiver (the TV) via infrared. </t>  <t> The team agreed to follow a user-centred approach and simplify the design by somehow minimising the number of buttons. </t>  <t> They plan to include an LCD screen to display relevant information. </t>  <t> Other functions are served by push buttons: OK, menu, screen sizing, AV, settings buttons, mute, digits 1-9, power, volume control, channel up/down with the last three types being prominent on the device. </t>  <t> The exact design and placement of the components will be decided in the next meeting. </t>  <t> Each member of the team will come for the next meeting with their views on function and design issues that they had not time to consolidate during this meeting. </t>  <t> The solution to complaints about remote controls being difficult to learn is to focus on an intuitive design instead of a thorough manual. </t>  <t> The idea of interchangeable fronts was mentioned again; if it were adopted, the company should be recognisable in all the available fronts as well as the remote itself. </t>  <t> The team agreed to follow a user-centred approach and simplify the design by somehow minimising the number of buttons. </t>  <t> An LCD screen is going to be used to display information, but would not be interactive. </t>  <t> The buttons are going to include: OK, menu, screen sizing, AV, settings buttons, mute, digits 1-9, power, volume control, channel up/down. </t>  <t> There is no need for a special button to recognise two-digit numbers. </t>  <t> The power button will be placed at the top separately. </t>  <t> The less frequently used buttons will not be hidden under a flip, as it had been previously suggested, as there are not that many of them; they will just be clearly separated from the more important ones. </t>  <t> A discussion on ergonomic solutions like placing the main buttons (power, channel selection, volume) where they can be easily reached with the thumb (as many users complain of RSI), did not reach a conclusion as to whether this would actually cause more repetitive movements. </t>  <t> Some advanced features, like LCD screen with program information or speech recognition, would be very important in order to attract their target group, but there are costing issues that have not been clarified yet. </t>  <t> There was some disagreement as to whether the LCD screen should be placed at the top or the bottom of the remote. </t>  <t> No consensus was reached regarding the positioning of the main buttons (zapping, volume, power) either: should they be placed close together or more scattered (to avoid RSI complaints)? </t>  <t> A special AV button for direct access to the video channel, although its necessity was disputed, because there are alternative solutions that make it obsolete. </t>

use. </t>  <t> The current fashion among younger people favours bright colours and fruit and vegetable themes: pertinent exchangeable fronts can express such trends on the remote. </t>  <t> Materials also need to be strong: the marketing expert suggested an iron-plate or titanium front. </t>  <t> The industrial designer suggested they use rubber push buttons (and no scroll wheel), simple battery (instead of solar cells or kinetic dynamo), and advanced chip. </t>  <t> Speech recognition can be implemented, but it does not link speech commands to remote control actions. </t>  <t> He also advised that the users within the target group prefer primary colours, soft textures and curved shapes. </t>  <t> The team drew a provisional prototype. </t>  <t> They placed the LCD below the buttons. </t>  <t> If it is implemented, a recording button, microphone and speaker need to be included in the design. </t>  <t> Finally, they decided to have a titanium case with plastic front and the company logo and slogan engraved. </t>  <t> Packages with a variety of changeable fronts will be launched. </t>  <t> The industrial designer and the user interface designer will work on a drawing of a prototype, where they will also sort out the details about the buttons. </t>  <t> The marketing expert will carry out an evaluation of the product. </t>  <t> The push buttons are going to be made of rubber. </t>  <t> The chip needs to be an advanced one to be compatible with the LCD screen that is going to be incorporated in the design. </t>  <t> Making changeable fascias can allow for the integration of this or future fashion trends in the device. </t>  <t> The team agreed to place the LCD at the bottom of the device, below the buttons. </t>  <t> TV settings will be included in menus there instead of having separate buttons for them. </t>  <t> They will implement speech recognition as well, because their target group like such gimmicks. </t>  <t> The case will be titanium with a plastic front with rounded buttons. </t>  <t> Parts of the front (like the bottom where the LCD is and the top corner where the logo is) will also be titanium. </t>  <t> The chip is going to be a standard one. </t>  <t> They will launch the product with various fronts to choose from including a couple of basic colours or fruit and vegetable themes to go with the current fashion. </t>  <t> The logo will be both at the front and the back of the remote; the company slogan will be engraved at the back. </t>  <t> The team found a possible conflict between the need for strong materials and the customers' preference for soft textures. </t>  <t> Plastic may be strong, but it does not necessarily look it. </t>  <t> The version of speech recognition discussed does not link voice commands to actual device actions. </t>  <t> Changing the front colours may make the front clash with the titanium, but it was also thought neutral enough for it not to matter. </t>  <t> They wondered whether to use both the logo and the slogan on the device and where it would be best for them to be placed. </t>

<t> The ID and UI presented the drawing of a prototype. </t>  <t> It is rounded, with the front made of hard plastic in different colours. </t>  <t> The back, as well as the lower part of the front are made of titanium. </t>  <t> The back has the logo and slogan of the company engraved in its middle. </t>  <t> The buttons include oval digit buttons, arrow-shaped channel and volume controls in the middle; below those, is the menu (for the LCD) and the video button. </t>  <t> The LCD can be found at the lower section of the device. </t>  <t> After the presentation, the product was evaluated. </t>  <t> This was done on a scale of 1(excellent)-7(very bad) on fancifulness, ease of use, finding the device when it is lost, hi-tech features, incorporation of fashion trends, and ergonomic design. </t>  <t> Because it was over budget, titanium was replaced by plastic and the speech recognition was discarded. </t>  <t> They thought it would have been more sensible to have the component costs before the prototype design. </t>  <t> Finally, the team evaluated the project process in terms of creativity (generally satisfied), leadership (the process was democratic, not happy with management), teamwork (happy with it), and means (SMARTboard was 'a disaster' and the digital pens only good for drawings). </t>  <t> *NA* </t>  <t> Despite disagreement regarding the position of the LCD (top or bottom), the screen was left at the bottom as it was in the prototype. </t>  <t> The sample speaker was taken out to bring the cost of the prototype down to the original budget of 12.50 euros. </t>  <t> They also decided to replace titanium with similar-looking plastic for the same reason. </t>  <t> There was criticism for the shape of the remote (thicker at the ends, thinner at the middle). </t>  <t> The project manager still disagreed on the position of the LCD: he would prefer it to be at the top. </t>  <t> The total cost of the prototype was 18.6 euros. </t>  <t> The team had to discuss which features should be discarded. </t>  <t> The only way was to go to a regular chip, but that would mean losing the LCD screen, which was integral to the design. </t>  <t> Replacing the titanium with plastic would have a detrimental effect on the looks of the remote. </t>  <t> The team discussed the possibility to leave the remaining cost at 14.10. </t>  <t> The SMARTboard was considered a disaster as they could not draw, and the digital pens can only be useful for drawings. </t>  <t> Some people thought that there was no advantage to using the SMARTboard instead of a normal blackboard and chalk, although you can save and reuse things with the former. </t>

<t> The industrial designer will look into what would be an appropriate technology to help users find their remote, when it is lost. </t>  <t> The project manager will add the minutes into the project A way to make this device different would be to use a scroll-wheel on the side with integrated button for volume control and mute. </t>  <t> Speech recognition can be implemented by adding a sample sensor and speaker on the remote. </t>  <t> The final decisions also included combined battery with solar cells. </t>  <t> The team will design a single-curved device with a scroll wheel and speech recognition, in black and yellow, the company colours. </t>  <t> The industrial designer and the user interface designer will work on a drawing of a prototype. </t>  <t> They will think about ways to make their product different from the others in the market. </t>  <t> They will also try to find a way to promote the corporate identity in the design of the look and feel and interface. </t>  <t> The ID and UI will also have to figure out whether to use rubber just for the buttons and side finish, or for the whole front of the remote. </t>  <t> The marketing expert will carry out a product evaluation. </t>  <t> Changeable covers for the remote control can link the product to current fashion trends, but also trends followed by other age groups. </t>  <t> A scroll wheel will be included in the design. </t>  <t> A regular chip will be needed for this. </t>  <t> A single-curved rubber casing can also be used. </t>  <t> LCD is not going to be implemented. </t>  <t> The preferred energy source was a combination of batteries and solar cells. </t>  <t> It is not clear whether a kinetic dynamo can be used, because it is unlikely that a user shakes the remote enough, as one would do with similarly powered watches. </t>  <t> The use of a scroll wheel with integrated button was debated, as not everyone was convinced of its use for this project. </t>  <t> Using the speech recognition on the device may not be convenient, since the remote will have to pointing towards the TV at the same time for the infrared to work. </t>  <t> LCD screens may add an extra hi-tech touch, but given all the other features, it might be too much. </t>  <t> The company colours (grey and yellow and black) did not seem sufficiently bright and trendy to everyone. </t>  <t> Printing an image on the remote to make it more colourful is doable, but cannot be done by the manufacturing department. </t>  <t> The front could have a rubber finish, or the buttons will be made of rubber. </t>  <t> It was debated that customers may prefer a total spongy texture, not just in the buttons and the sides of the remote. </t>

<t> The UI and ID presented a prototype drawing of the remote control design. </t>  <t> It can be used as a normal remote, but the speech recognition also provides a more advanced alternative interface. </t>  <t> The speech recognition works as a finding mechanism as well. </t>  <t> The rubber case is yellow with grey or black, with buttons either made of plastic or rubber. </t>  <t> An extra button could activate/deactivate the voice recognition. </t>  <t> The prototype proved extremely over budget. </t>  <t> The main contributing factors were the solar cell and speech recognition. </t>  <t> One way to compensate for the loss of features, but still attract their target group, would be to add more colour to the design. </t>  <t> After the costing, the original prototype was evaluated on a scale of 1(excellent)-7(very bad). </t>  <t> The criteria used were fancifulness (2), technological innovation (2), ease of use (2.5), whether it is easy to find (1), sponginess (1.5), number of features (1). </t>  <t> Finally, the team evaluated the project process in terms of creativity (choices too narrow), leadership and teamwork (happy with it, but they missed communicating in between meetings), and means (SMARTboard was not satisfactory, but the digital pens were alright, but not too useful). </t>  <t> The delay in providing costs of components was criticised. </t>  <t> The prototype will have to be redesigned, so that it is compatible with the budget constraints.. </t>  <t> The idea to include a solar cell as a power source had to be abandoned, due to the escalated costs. </t>  <t> The same happened with the speech recognition. </t>  <t> In order for the cost to come down to the original budget of 12.50, they also had to replace the rubber of the buttons with plastic and not use a curved design. </t>  <t> The prototype proved extremely over budget. </t>  <t> It would cost 22 euros. </t>  <t> The team thought all the changes to accommodate the budget requirements made a very dull device. </t>  <t> It was suggested that they go for a completely simple design so as to maximise the profit, although this was not what was asked in the project requirements. </t>  <t> The device cannot be a hi-tech, innovative one any more. </t>

<t> Customers are willing to pay more for fancier looking remotes. </t>  <t> They like innovative technology like speech recognition and LCD screens. </t>  <t> It also transpires that remotes are easy to lose. </t>  <t> Everyone agreed that they need to incorporate a locating mechanism in their design, and that changeable covers could make appealing-looking remotes. </t>  <t> The need for clarity of button functions was mentioned. </t>  <t> On the other hand, materials should be more durable. </t>  <t> The function of the remote is relatively simple: by pressing a button a current is passed to the chip, and defines what signal is to be sent to the receiver (the TV) via infrared. </t>  <t> There are some new requirements: the target group will be people below 40, the device will have to be for TV only, they should ignore the teletext function, and, also, the remote should be recognisable as a Real Reaction product. </t>  <t> They drew some of their ideas, and discussed the positioning of the buttons and the LCD. </t>  <t> The most used buttons are going to be placed on top. </t>  <t> It might be possible to use a charger for the remote. </t>  <t> The concept of the design will be finalised in the next meeting. </t>  <t> The ID will present the components concept. </t>  <t> He will also check into the importance and possibility of using rechargeable batteries and a charger. </t>  <t> The UI will present the user interface concept. </t>  <t> He will also draw some ideas for the shape of the remote. </t>  <t> The marketing expert will need to find information on current trends and see into the financial issues concerning the integration of a charger. </t>  <t> The team will also examine whether they can use an LCD and/or speech recognition. </t>  <t> Finally, they will try to think of a name for their product. </t>  <t> The target group will be people below 40. </t>  <t> The remote will only be used for TV. </t>  <t> The company colours and slogan will have to be shown on the device. </t>  <t> Buttons should be made bigger, with clearly defined functions and of durable materials to avoid fading of the symbols. </t>  <t> It would be a good idea to integrate a mechanism for finding the remote control, when the user loses it. </t>  <t> A button that sticks on the TV could be pressed to make the lost remote beep, and perhaps also light up. </t>  <t> The remote is going to be a universal one. </t>  <t> Because symbols may fade, the additional covers could include those. </t>  <t> The remote will need to be different from those available in the market in terms of shape and colour. </t>  <t> The important buttons will be on top. </t>  <t> Speech recognition and LCD screens could be added to the remote control, but they might be too expensive for this project. </t>  <t> The industrial designer wondered whether the remote should be universal or programmable. </t>  <t> Symbols on remotes fade with time. </t>  <t> It may not be technically possible for a universal remote control to create menus for various advanced settings on the TV itself. </t>  <t> Different TVs have different functions incorporated in their built-in menus, making it hard to know in advance which buttons you can do without on the remote. </t>  <t> It is difficult to organise or limit the number of buttons in a way that makes the remote easier to use. </t>  <t> The team also discussed extensively the positioning of various buttons. </t>  <t> Using a charger for the remote may be too expensive. </t>  <t> Consumers claim they would pay more for a remote with LCD screen, but adding the component might be too expensive. </t>  <t> In the case where it is added, the issue would be whether to place it at the top or the bottom of the remote. </t>

<t> The UI and ID presented a prototype drawing of the remote control design. </t>  <t> The rubber case is yellow with black buttons and dark yellow for the menus. </t>  <t> There are buttons for teletext, favourite channel, mute and OK. </t>  <t> It incorporates both LCD screen and speech recognition. </t>  <t> The prototype proved over budget (17 euros). </t>  <t> The main contributing factors were the LCD and speech recognition. </t>  <t> The latter was taken out, along with the special colour. </t>  <t> Everyone agreed that the financial information should not have been given to them at the last moment. </t>  <t> After the costing, the original prototype was evaluated on a scale of 1(excellent)-7(very bad). </t>  <t> The criteria used were look and feel (1), whether it is easy to find (1), whether it is easy to learn (2), use of LCD (3), speech recognition (7), trendiness (2). </t>  <t> Finally, the team evaluated the project process in terms of creativity (satisfactory), leadership and teamwork (happy with it, but they missed communicating in between meetings), and means (SMARTboard could be improved in terms of response time, the digital pens could not be used on more than one page at the same time). </t>  <t> Finally, the decided to call their design Triple-R. </t>  <t> The PM is going to finish the project report. </t>  <t> The UI and ID will send him their design to include. </t>  <t> Because the prototype was over budget, the team decided to take out the speech recognition from the design. </t>  <t> They also discarded the special colour, and decided to rely on the changeable covers for an attractive look. </t>  <t> The remote control is going to be called Triple-R. </t>  <t> The production cost was 17 euros, 4.5 more than the budget. </t>  <t> It was imperative that some of the features had to be taken out. </t>  <t> There was disagreement over whether the special colour should be scrapped and the look to rely on the separate covers. </t>  <t> Other solutions, like abandoning the curve of the casing or replace the rubber with plastic were also suggested. </t>  <t> They were also not allowed to raise the budget limit. </t>  <t> The precise use of the LCD was not defined: it could be used for TV configuration, or, if possible, for displaying the TV programme and previews. </t>  <t> Although the SMARTboard was useful to draw ideas quickly , it could be improved in terms of response time. </t>  <t> Similarly, the digital pens did not allow the user to work on more than one page at a time. </t>  <t> The team
